pageProps.contentHtml:
Week 9 Discussion Notes

Table of Contents

  • Surface Integrals

Surface Integrals

Surface integrals are similar to line integrals: line integrals are integrals on 1D curves, and surface integrals are integrals on 2D "curves" (i.e., on 2D surfaces). The steps for calculating a surface integral are basically the same, except things are harder just because surfaces live in 3D space.

A vector surface integral is called a flux integral and looks like

∬SF⃗⋅dS⃗\iint_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{F} \cdot \diff\vec{S}∬S​F⋅dS

where S\mathscr{S}S is an oriented surface, and the steps to calculate one are:

  1. Parametrize S\mathscr{S}S via a function G(u,v)G\p{u, v}G(u,v) with domain D\mathscr{D}D.

  2. Calculate the normal vector N⃗(u,v)\vec{N}\p{u, v}N(u,v), which is either

    Gu×GvorGv×GuG_u \times G_v \quad\text{or}\quad G_v \times G_uGu​×Gv​orGv​×Gu​

    depending on the orientation of S\mathscr{S}S. (Note that Gu×Gv=−Gv×GuG_u \times G_v = -G_v \times G_uGu​×Gv​=−Gv​×Gu​, so based on the orientation, you may or may not need to multiply your cross product by −1-1−1.)

  3. Plug in everything to get a 2D integral:

    ∬SF⃗⋅dS⃗=∬DF⃗(G(u,v))⋅N⃗(u,v) du dv.\iint_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{F} \cdot \diff{\vec{S}} = \iint_{\mathscr{D}} \vec{F}\p{G\p{u, v}} \cdot \vec{N}\p{u, v} \,\diff{u} \,\diff{v}.∬S​F⋅dS=∬D​F(G(u,v))⋅N(u,v)dudv.

  4. Integrate like normal.

Example 1.

Calculate ∬SF⃗⋅dS⃗\displaystyle\iint_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{F} \cdot \diff\vec{S}∬S​F⋅dS, with F⃗(x,y,z)=⟨0,3,x⟩\vec{F}\p{x, y, z} = \ang{0, 3, x}F(x,y,z)=⟨0,3,x⟩ and S\mathscr{S}S is the part of the sphere x2+y2+z2=9x^2 + y^2 + z^2 = 9x2+y2+z2=9 where x≥0x \geq 0x≥0, y≥0y \geq 0y≥0, and z≥0z \geq 0z≥0, with outward pointing normal.
Solution.

First, we need to parametrize this region. Since it's a part of a sphere, we can base our parametrization on spherical coordinates:

G(θ,φ)=⟨ρsin⁡φcos⁡θ,ρsin⁡φsin⁡θ,ρcos⁡φ⟩G\p{\theta, \phi} = \ang{\rho\sin\phi\cos\theta, \rho\sin\phi\sin\theta, \rho\cos\phi}G(θ,φ)=⟨ρsinφcosθ,ρsinφsinθ,ρcosφ⟩

The sphere has radius 333, so ρ=3\rho = 3ρ=3. To get x≥0x \geq 0x≥0 and y≥0y \geq 0y≥0, we need 0≤θ≤π20 \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2}0≤θ≤2π​, and to get z≥0z \geq 0z≥0, we need 0≤φ≤π20 \leq \phi \leq \frac{\pi}{2}0≤φ≤2π​, so the parametrization is

{G(θ,φ)=⟨3sin⁡φcos⁡θ,3sin⁡φsin⁡θ,3cos⁡φ⟩,D={(θ,φ) | 0≤θ≤π2, 0≤φ≤π2}.\begin{cases} G\p{\theta, \phi} = \ang{3\sin\phi\cos\theta, 3\sin\phi\sin\theta, 3\cos\phi}, \\ \mathscr{D} = \set{\p{\theta, \phi} \st 0 \leq \theta \leq \frac{\pi}{2},\ 0 \leq \phi \leq \frac{\pi}{2}}. \end{cases}{G(θ,φ)=⟨3sinφcosθ,3sinφsinθ,3cosφ⟩,D={(θ,φ)∣∣​0≤θ≤2π​, 0≤φ≤2π​}.​

Next, let's calculate N⃗\vec{N}N:

Gθ=⟨−3sin⁡φsin⁡θ,3sin⁡φcos⁡θ,0⟩Gφ=⟨3cos⁡φcos⁡θ,3cos⁡φsin⁡θ,−3sin⁡φ⟩Gθ×Gφ=⟨−9sin⁡2φcos⁡θ,−9sin⁡2φsin⁡θ,−9sin⁡φcos⁡φ⟩\begin{aligned} G_\theta &= \ang{-3\sin\phi\sin\theta, 3\sin\phi\cos\theta, 0} \\ G_\phi &= \ang{3\cos\phi\cos\theta, 3\cos\phi\sin\theta, -3\sin\phi} \\ G_\theta \times G_\phi &= \ang{-9\sin^2\phi\cos\theta, -9\sin^2\phi\sin\theta, -9\sin\phi\cos\phi} \end{aligned}Gθ​Gφ​Gθ​×Gφ​​=⟨−3sinφsinθ,3sinφcosθ,0⟩=⟨3cosφcosθ,3cosφsinθ,−3sinφ⟩=⟨−9sin2φcosθ,−9sin2φsinθ,−9sinφcosφ⟩​

To figure out what N⃗\vec{N}N is, we need to figure out whether Gθ×GφG_\theta \times G_\phiGθ​×Gφ​ points inwards or outwards, which we can do by just testing it at a point. We can test it at the point (x,y,z)=(3,0,0)\p{x, y, z} = \p{3, 0, 0}(x,y,z)=(3,0,0), which corresponds to (θ,φ)=(0,π2)\p{\theta, \phi} = \p{0, \frac{\pi}{2}}(θ,φ)=(0,2π​), so

Gθ(0,π2)×Gφ(0,π2)=⟨−9,0,0⟩,G_\theta\p{0, \frac{\pi}{2}} \times G_\phi\p{0, \frac{\pi}{2}} = \ang{-9, 0, 0},Gθ​(0,2π​)×Gφ​(0,2π​)=⟨−9,0,0⟩,

which points inwards. This means we need to reverse it to get an outward pointing normal, i.e.,

N⃗=−Gθ×Gφ=⟨9sin⁡2φcos⁡θ,9sin⁡2φsin⁡θ,9sin⁡φcos⁡φ⟩.\vec{N} = -G_\theta \times G_\phi = \ang{9\sin^2\phi\cos\theta, 9\sin^2\phi\sin\theta, 9\sin\phi\cos\phi}.N=−Gθ​×Gφ​=⟨9sin2φcosθ,9sin2φsinθ,9sinφcosφ⟩.

Finally, we just plug everything in:

∬SF⃗⋅dS⃗=∬DF⃗(G(θ,φ))⋅N⃗(θ,φ) dθ dφ=∫0π2∫0π2⟨0,3,3sin⁡φcos⁡θ⟩⋅⟨9sin⁡2φcos⁡θ,9sin⁡2φsin⁡θ,9sin⁡φcos⁡φ⟩ dθ dφ=∫0π2∫0π227sin⁡2φsin⁡θ+26sin⁡2φcos⁡φcos⁡θ dθ dφ=2712(3π+4).\begin{aligned} \iint_{\mathscr{S}} \vec{F} \cdot \diff\vec{S} &= \iint_{\mathscr{D}} \vec{F}\p{G\p{\theta, \phi}} \cdot \vec{N}\p{\theta, \phi} \,\diff\theta \,\diff\phi \\ &= \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \ang{0, 3, 3\sin\phi\cos\theta} \cdot \ang{9\sin^2\phi\cos\theta, 9\sin^2\phi\sin\theta, 9\sin\phi\cos\phi} \,\diff\theta \,\diff\phi \\ &= \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{2}} 27\sin^2\phi\sin\theta + 26\sin^2\phi\cos\phi\cos\theta \,\diff\theta \,\diff\phi \\ &= \boxed{\frac{27}{12}\p{3\pi + 4}}. \end{aligned}∬S​F⋅dS​=∬D​F(G(θ,φ))⋅N(θ,φ)dθdφ=∫02π​​∫02π​​⟨0,3,3sinφcosθ⟩⋅⟨9sin2φcosθ,9sin2φsinθ,9sinφcosφ⟩dθdφ=∫02π​​∫02π​​27sin2φsinθ+26sin2φcosφcosθdθdφ=1227​(3π+4)​.​

(Like always, the hardest part of the problem is getting to the second line, i.e., writing down the exact integral you need to calculate.)
